data.title: Interesting architecture and statue
data.text: A very good example of an old public building.  Inside is a warren of offices with.wood trim in abundance.  A large beautiful statue of Neptune is in the lobby.

data.title: GREAT ARCHITECTURE
data.text: This is a very beautiful example of great architecture. It's a must see in Minneapolis if you like to look at buildings.

data.title: Wow this building has great architecture
data.text: I came here on our last day in Minneapolis. City Hall was a few blocks from our hotel and I only wish I had spent more time exploring this building.

data.title: A remarkable surprise!
data.text: I had to visit the police records department this morning.  I entered the building from the 5th Street side and declared to the records clerk what a lovely building it is.  Well, she directed me to the rotunda on the 4th street side.  Wow. Wow. Wow.  Spectacular five story atrium with a glorious statue of the Father of the Waters.  And the stained glass!  I will definitely be back for the tour at noon on the third Wednesday of the month.

data.title: Beautiful Old Building Downtown
data.text: I love the old architecture in the building from the clock tower to the basement tunnels that connect the skyway. The red granite make the building unique. The inside granite steps show the wear of millions of steps taken. The old offices and doors were built to last for generations. It is an amazing building to walk around in.

data.title: Amazing interior space
data.text: The Richardsonian Romanesque exterior architecture is nice contrast to the concrete and glass structures in the surrounding area.   The size and style of City Hall reflect the ambitions of a young Minneapolis in the late 19th century.  Main interior lobby is amazing and worth checking out.  The building contains the office of the mayor, city council, and some city services.  Office portion is ho-hum - not worth taking time to see unless you have business with the City.   City Hall is one of the better architectural gems in Minneapolis and worth visiting if you are an architecture aficionado.

data.title: Cool architecture!
data.text: I love this building! Sit in the common area at the Government Center and watch the Perigrine Falcons!

data.title: Great history here!
data.text: I have this memory of my first visit some 40 years ago. There is a clock tower on the building with a clock on all four sides.  To remember where I parked, I simply thought all I had to do was walk away from the clock...'nuff said.  LOL.  There is also a bell chime in the tower and they play hourly to mark the time, but on special occasions actually play tunes.  The architecture is marvelous and the ever changing displays depict our history and current lives.  Not to be missed.

data.title: Beautiful Wedding at City Hall
data.text:
This building is a must see for everyone
There are a number of locations for events......We had our Wedding Ceremony in "chambers"
A real special feeling landmark in Minneapolis

data.title: Very Historical
data.text: Neat building to see and offers a lot to architecture buffs. Interesting to see but not much to do if you go to visit.

data.title: Clock face bigger than Big Ben.
data.text: Try not to get sent here. Connected to Light rail and close to bike links. Statue of Hubert Humphrey: Mayor of Minneapolis, founder of DFL and civil rights champion, VP to LBJ and Democratic candidate to presidency with loss in 1968 to Nixon outside to greet you.

data.title: Make sure you walk through the lobby!
data.text: Just wandering in to view the architecture and statue is worth the visit. The upper floors are supposedly haunted by the souls of the hanged, but I've not seen them. The building itself is fantastic and an excellent stop for all visitors.

data.title: HISTORIC SYMBOL OF MINNEAPOLIS ....DIGNIFIED YET WELCOMING...
data.text:
CLEARLY A GEM OF RESTORATION, IT IS STILL THE WORKING CENTER OF CITY GOVERNMENT....no it is not a museum, city meeting agendas are posted around, its as hussle and bussle of people doing the city's work...police, city workers, staff and the lobbyists, the petitioners, the complainers, the school groups getting a look at "democracy in action"....and it all happens in this great stained glass and marble monument to the over 100 years of activity.
    We went there to show some out of town relatives where Mpls works on its city (Its also a great place to go for a few hours when weather is horrid outside)...So we treked in...got a building map, asked for a tour and discovered how many nooks and crannies exist there...archives...police...voter's registration, beautifully impressive city council meeting room and of course an impressive Mayor's Office. 
    Elevators got us all around this huge place pretty well. The most impressive room is the atrium with the massive sculpture of Father of the Waters (Minnesota's Mississippi River). Stained glass is not a part of contemporary or suburban public buildings so seeing so much of it here in this building does indicate how proud early citizens were of their new city government. We were proud too after finishing our tour..a good civics lesson.
SUGGESTIONS:
Parking is easy here most times of day, just drive around the block (avoiding all the police cars that seem to be ringing the block}, and enter the underground public garage. Its a bargain price, dry and safe.
Food  or snacks....Anything edible is hard to come by here. This building really needs to develop something...like developing its great brick/stone basement into a Ratskeller-like eating place like that at the Minnesota state capital ...imagine having coffee, a bowl of chili or a sandwich in the subterranean restaurant there. That might even be a money earner for the city ! How fun for visitors too.
Be sure to see the restored historic City Council Chambers.
SUMMARY: A must do for visitors and citizens alike....great place to bring out-of-town relatives. Its attached to downtown skyway system via an underground tunnel between this city hall building and the adjacent county government highrise. Have a look at that building too.!

data.title: Haunted Halls No More
data.text: Minneapolis City Hall has been transformed from the dreary old days of the drunk tank and the gallows to a bright welcoming space that houses essential city departments and the City Council. The marble floors, statutes and bannisters retain their elegance after more than a 100 years. Walk up the grand staircase to see the stained glass and the bee hives in the interior court yard.

data.title: beautiful architecture
data.text: inside and out - however parking is at a premium - best to use mass transit when touring downtown, then walk

data.title: Occupy Movement
data.text: I was stopping in at a occupy movement and noticed the police were quite nice  and on friendly terms with occupiers.

data.title: Interesting building
data.text: The outside of the building looks very nice, especially with the green roof. The inside is very beautiful as well.

data.title: Incredible architecture
data.text: If you enjoy walking around beautiful old buildings and admiring the architecture of the past this would be a fun place to visit and just explore around. The marble staircases and huge cathedral ceiling with stained glass windows will take your breath away. The building is kind of confusing though. Make sure you go up high enough to get to the main part of the building. It is also a confusing place if you have to use it for real business in that the different rooms like voter registration are marked poorly and people don't direct you very well even though they try. Location signs are not kept up to date.

data.title: GO INSIDE!!
data.text: This is right off the train and you can grab this attraction and be in awe for as little as 20 minutes. The outside is monolithic and the inside is a gem of a time-trip. For history buffs read up on it so you can understand the names attached to some of the great things that this city is known for like Pillsbury.  It speaks to a time great things were built for a generation that was only an inconceivable dream.  MN is a philanthropic state and its founders changed the nations view of public space in this building.

data.title: Landmark
data.text: Nice stone outside and marble inside.  Attended a wedding celebration there previously.  Minneapolis City Attorney and Police are located there.  Definitely worth checking out if you are downtown.
